Supernova

Usage example:

from sspike.supernova import Supernova

model = 'Nakazato_2013'
progenitor = {'mass':  20,
              'metal': 0.02,
              't_rev': 300}
transformation = 'NoTransformation'
distance = 5.0
sn = Supernova(model, progenitor, transformation, distance)
class sspike.supernova.Supernova(model, progenitor, transform, distance, t_bins=1, t_start=None, t_end=None)

Simulation parameters and directory information.

Parameters

  • model (str) – Name of supernova model type from snewpy.

  • progenitor (dict) – Model specific simulation parameters.

  • transform (str) – Name of transformation type for snewpy to apply.

  • distance (float) – Distance to supernova in kpc.

  • t_bins (int, default 1) – Number of time bins.

  • t_start (float, optional) – Start time for simulation if not earliest model time.

  • t_end (float, optional) – End time for simulation if not latest model time.

sn_name

Name indicating model type and progenitor parameters.

Type

str

xform

Transformation abbreviation for folders and plots.

Type

str

t_min

Model specific simulation start time.

Type

float

t_max

Model specific simulation end time.

Type

float

model_dir

Supernova simulation directory path.

Type

str

sim_file

Path to simulation file: f”{models_dir}/{sn.model}/{sn.sim_path}”

Type

str

prog_dir

Directory for sspike outputs varied by model, progenitor, and x-form.

Type

str

sn_dir

Directory path for sspike outputs varied by distance and transform.

Type

str

bin_name

Folder name for bin-dependent files: f’b{t_bins}s{t_start}e{t_end}’.

Type

str

bin_dir

Directory for sspike outputs varied by binning.

Type

str

record

Path to file for keeping track of processing history.

Type

str

tar_file

File path to tarball created by snewpy: f’{models_dir}/

Type

str

lum_file

File path for model luminosities: f’{sn.prog_dir}/luminosity.csv’.

Type

str

flu_file

File path(s) to extracted fluences: f”{sn.bin_dir}/{sn.sn_name_}{i}.dat”.

Type

list of str

Notes

All parameters are also set as attributes.

bin_times()

Create arrays of start, mid, and end times.

Returns

(ts, tm, te)

Return type

np.array
